column1: It was one of their happy mornings. They trotted along and sat down together
column2: with no thought that life would ever change much for them: they would only get bigger and not go to school
column3: and it would always be like the holidays; they would always live together and be fond of each other. And the mill with its booming—the great chestnut-tree under which they played at houses—their own little river
column5: where the banks seemed like home
column6: and Tom was always seeing the water-rats
column7: while Maggie gathered the purple plumy tops of the reeds
column8: which she forgot and dropped afterward—above all
column10: along which they wandered with a sense of travel

column14: or to see the Great Ash which had once wailed and groaned like a man—these things would always be just the same to them. Tom thought people were at a disadvantage who lived on any other spot of the globe; and Maggie
